### Complaints about landlords or letting agents ###

If you're unhappy with the way your landlord or letting agent has responded, you could consider making a complaint. For more information, see:  [https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/private_renting/complaints_about_letting_agents](https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/private_renting/complaints_about_letting_agents)

### Consider organising the repair work yourself ###

If the problem is relatively small, you could arrange for the repairs to be done. However, it's important to keep your landlord informed, and follow a step-by-step process. 

You must not stop paying rent without notice, but you may be able to take the cost of repairs out of your rent. See more about [organising repairs yourself]( https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/doing_the_repairs_if_your_landlord_wont) on the Shelter website.

If the problem is relatively small, you could arrange for the repairs to be done. However, it's important to keep your landlord informed, and follow a step-by-step process. You must not stop paying rent without notice, but you may be able to take the cost of repairs out of your rent. See more about [organising repairs yourself]( https://england.shelter.org.uk/housing_advice/repairs/doing_the_repairs_if_your_landlord_wont) on the Shelter website.

### Make a complaint to the local council ###

You can complain if you don't think the council has dealt with your problem properly. Ask for a copy of their: 

- housing enforcement policy 
- complaints procedure 

Check the council have followed their own housing enforcement policy. If not, you can use the complaints procedure. 

You can use this service to complain about your local council: [https://www.gov.uk/complain-about-your-council](https://www.gov.uk/complain-about-your-council)

### Make a complaint to the Local Government and Social Care Ombudsman ###

If you're not satisfied with the council's response to your complaint, you can complain to the Local Government & Social Care Ombudsman. See: [https://www.lgo.org.uk/](https://www.lgo.org.uk/)

### Free legal help and advice ###

If you're on a low income, you may qualify for free legal help. See: [https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/law-and-courts/legal-system/finding-free-or-affordable-legal-help/](https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/law-and-courts/legal-system/finding-free-or-affordable-legal-help/)

### Gathering information ###
Before going to court, it is important to gather together enough information to prove the case. This is likely to include:

- proof of when the landlord was told about the problem and copies of any letters and emails
- photographs of the problem 
- any evidence available from experts (eg surveyors, environmental health officers)
- the tenancy agreement and other documents relating to the tenancy
- any relevant medical reports detailing the effects of the bad housing conditions on the health or stress levels of the occupants
- details of any costs incurred as a result of the disrepair.

[https://england.shelter.org.uk/legal/housing_conditions/taking_action_on_disrepair/county_court_action/gathering_information](https://england.shelter.org.uk/legal/housing_conditions/taking_action_on_disrepair/county_court_action/gathering_information)

### Give your landlord time to reply ###

You should give the landlord 20 days to reply and put things right. If they don't do so, you can the proceed with making a claim.
